trans-unit.source: A walk through on how to build an node.js express application that uses Reliable Actors and runs on top of the Azure Service Fabric platform.
trans-unit.target: A walk through on how to build an node.js express application that uses Reliable Actors and runs on top of the Azure Service Fabric platform.

trans-unit.source: Node.js and reliable actors: a winning combination
trans-unit.target: Node.js and reliable actors: a winning combination

trans-unit.source: This article is an overview on how you can build an application that uses node.js and Reliable Actors.
trans-unit.target: This article is an overview on how you can build an application that uses node.js and Reliable Actors.

trans-unit.source: The final solution is a blend of javascript code used mainly to provide the frontend side of the app (Web/Rest APIs) and C# for more complex computation.

trans-unit.source: Using Reliable Actors in the Node.js app
trans-unit.target: Using Reliable Actors in the Node.js app

trans-unit.source: Now that the project structure is set, we can focus on the code that allow the node.js application to connect to Reliable Actors in the cluster like you can do from a .NET application.
trans-unit.target: Now that the project structure is set, we can focus on the code that allow the node.js application to connect to Reliable Actors in the cluster like you can do from a .NET application.

trans-unit.source: The scenario we want to enable is to buld a node.js application that act as frontend/gateway for client application and expose an web-based application or a set of rest APIs a client app can use.
trans-unit.target: The scenario we want to enable is to buld a node.js application that act as frontend/gateway for client application and expose an web-based application or a set of rest APIs a client app can use.

trans-unit.source: Node.js provides the frontend of the app while Reliable Actors provide the scalable and reliable 'application server' layer of the app.
trans-unit.target: Node.js provides the frontend of the app while Reliable Actors provide the scalable and reliable 'application server' layer of the app.

trans-unit.source: In Service Fabric, Reliable Actors can be invoked by using the [ActorProxy class](service-fabric-reliable-actors-introduction.md#actor-communication).
trans-unit.target: In Service Fabric, Reliable Actors can be invoked by using the [ActorProxy class](service-fabric-reliable-actors-introduction.md#actor-communication).

trans-unit.source: Luckly there is a great node.js module that can be use to call into .NET code: [Edge.js](https://github.com/tjanczuk/edge).
trans-unit.target: Luckly there is a great node.js module that can be use to call into .NET code: [Edge.js](https://github.com/tjanczuk/edge).

trans-unit.source: You can use the instructions on the github repo to find out how to install edge on your machine.
trans-unit.target: You can use the instructions on the github repo to find out how to install edge on your machine.

trans-unit.source: After you install edge either using NPM or the NPM UI in Visual Studio, you need to move the new installed module in the node_modules directory under the Code subdirectory (we changed the structure of the node.js project and moved all code under the PackageRoot/Code directory).
trans-unit.target: After you install edge either using NPM or the NPM UI in Visual Studio, you need to move the new installed module in the node_modules directory under the Code subdirectory (we changed the structure of the node.js project and moved all code under the PackageRoot/Code directory).

trans-unit.source: You can find good examples in the edge.js repo on Github on how you can use edge to call .NET code, the following is a simple example of how the code looks like when you need to call Reliable Actors using the ActorProxy class.
trans-unit.target: You can find good examples in the edge.js repo on Github on how you can use edge to call .NET code, the following is a simple example of how the code looks like when you need to call Reliable Actors using the ActorProxy class.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The ActorProxy uses the Actor interface in order to know which actor it should connect to.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The ActorProxy uses the Actor interface in order to know which actor it should connect to.

trans-unit.source: In order for the managed code running in the node.js process to be able to instantiate that class, the Actor interface assembly needs to be copied in the code directory like the other Service Fabric dlls.
trans-unit.target: In order for the managed code running in the node.js process to be able to instantiate that class, the Actor interface assembly needs to be copied in the code directory like the other Service Fabric dlls.
